commonpatterns.title: There's not much to say
commonpatterns.description: Used when you feel there is nothing more to add or discuss.
examples: Honestly, there's not much to say about the situation.
There's not much to say—everything is clear.

commonpatterns.title: It's out of my question
commonpatterns.description: Used to express that something is completely unacceptable or impossible for you.
examples: Going on a trip right now is out of my question.
It's out of my question to lend him more money.

commonpatterns.title: Correct me if I am wrong
commonpatterns.description: Used before expressing your opinion when you're not sure if it's completely correct.
examples: Correct me if I’m wrong, but wasn’t she here yesterday?
Correct me if I’m wrong, but I think we already discussed this.

commonpatterns.title: Either this or that
commonpatterns.description: Used to express a choice between two options.
examples: You can choose either this or that, but not both.
It’s either this or that—make a decision.

commonpatterns.title: I am as before
commonpatterns.description: Used to express that you haven't changed or your situation remains the same.
examples: Don't worry about me, I am as before.
Nothing new—I’m as before.

commonpatterns.title: I have never given it much thought
commonpatterns.description: Used when you haven’t really considered or thought deeply about something.
examples: Honestly, I’ve never given it much thought.
I have never given it much thought until now.

commonpatterns.title: It's not a big deal
commonpatterns.description: Used to say something is not very important.
examples: Relax, it’s not a big deal.
It’s not a big deal if we’re a few minutes late.

commonpatterns.title: There are downsides to this
commonpatterns.description: Used to acknowledge disadvantages of a situation or decision.
examples: Sure, working from home is nice, but there are downsides to this.
There are downsides to this plan we need to consider.

commonpatterns.title: I won't be taken back by anything
commonpatterns.description: Used to express that nothing will shock or surprise you.
examples: After everything I’ve seen, I won’t be taken back by anything.
His reaction didn’t take me back at all.

commonpatterns.title: I will do my own way
commonpatterns.description: Used to express that you’ll follow your own path or method.
examples: I respect your opinion, but I will do my own way.
Let me do it my own way.

commonpatterns.title: It's you who are to
commonpatterns.description: Used for emphasizing responsibility or blame.
examples: It’s you who are to blame for this.
It’s you who are to fix the problem.

commonpatterns.title: Our main aim today is to
commonpatterns.description: Used when stating the main objective of a discussion or activity.
examples: Our main aim today is to finalize the project.
Our main aim today is to improve team communication.

commonpatterns.title: What a fuss you made
commonpatterns.description: Used to express annoyance or surprise at someone overreacting.
examples: What a fuss you made over a small mistake!
He made such a fuss for nothing.

commonpatterns.title: That's all I have to say about that
commonpatterns.description: Used to conclude your opinion on a subject.
examples: It was unfair, and that’s all I have to say about that.
I’ve said what I wanted, that’s all I have to say about that.

commonpatterns.title: It might seem pointless
commonpatterns.description: Used when something may appear to lack purpose or value.
examples: It might seem pointless now, but it will matter later.
Sometimes hard work might seem pointless, but it pays off.

commonpatterns.title: That's the way it is
commonpatterns.description: Used to express acceptance of a situation.
examples: Some things can’t be changed—that’s the way it is.
Life isn’t always fair. That’s the way it is.

commonpatterns.title: I feel like I was being punished
commonpatterns.description: Used to describe a situation that feels unfair or unpleasant.
examples: During the meeting, I felt like I was being punished.
Why do I feel like I was being punished for being honest?

commonpatterns.title: This is nonsense
commonpatterns.description: Used to express disbelief or disapproval.
examples: This is nonsense! None of this makes sense.
Stop arguing—this is nonsense.

commonpatterns.title: It doesn't make much of a difference
commonpatterns.description: Used to say that the outcome is similar no matter the choice.
examples: It doesn’t make much of a difference whether we go now or later.
Choose any color—it doesn’t make much of a difference.

commonpatterns.title: You don't know what it is like
commonpatterns.description: Used to express that someone cannot understand your experience.
examples: You don’t know what it is like to be in my position.
Unless you’ve been there, you don’t know what it is like.

commonpatterns.title: She is indelible
commonpatterns.description: Used to describe someone unforgettable or who leaves a lasting impact.
examples: Her influence on the team is indelible.
She is indelible—no one can forget her kindness.

commonpatterns.title: What's gotten into you today?
commonpatterns.description: Used when someone behaves unusually or unexpectedly.
examples: You’re so energetic today—what’s gotten into you?
What’s gotten into you today? You’re acting strange.

commonpatterns.title: It doesn't add up something to me
commonpatterns.description: Used when something doesn't make sense logically.
examples: His explanation doesn’t add up to me.
This story doesn’t add up something to me—it sounds fishy.
